test

Class LiteDriver

  • java.lang.Object
    • test.LiteDriver

  • public class LiteDriver
extends java.lang.Object
    I simple unit test driver. To use LiteDriver, you must first annotate classes and methods with the LiteClass and LiteTest annotations respectively. LiteDriver will use these annotations to find tests to be queued and run.
    The basic steps to running tests are as follows:
    1. Write tests and annotate the tests and their classes with @LiteTest and @LiteClass
    2. Queue all the tests that you would like to run for that particular test run
    3. Call executeQueuedTests() to allow the TestDriver to run the tests
    4. Call a print method to see the results of the tests
    5. Call reset() to prep the TestDriver for a new set of tests
    NOTE: The runTests() method may be invoked to automate these steps for a single package or class.

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      boolean FULL_TRACE_DEFAULT
      false is the default for whether or not to print the full stack trace in tests results
      boolean RECURSE_DEFAULT
      false is the default for whether or not to scan packages recursively.
      boolean SCAN_NON_TEST_CLASS_DEFAULT
      false is the default for whether or not to print scan classes that are not marked with the @LiteClass annotation
      java.lang.String TARGET_DOT_NAME_DEFAULT
      "" is the default for the target starting at the testing root that was set up in the constructor originally

    • Constructor Detail

      • LiteDriver

        public LiteDriver(java.lang.String pathToSrc)
        See LiteDriver(String, String)

      • LiteDriver

        public LiteDriver(java.lang.String pathToSrc,
          java.lang.String localTestRoot)
        Sets up the test driver to scan files for tests. Because a project's content root cannot be identified at runtime, the user must supply the path (dot or slash separated) to the base directory for all .java files. In many instances this will be simply "src", but if you have configured more that one content root or developing in android, it could be something like "app.src.main.java" where java is the beginning of your code package structure.
        You may optionally include another dot path beginning with the first folder after the content root that indicates the root of all of the test classes. This will be added as a prefix to all package or class names passed to queueTests() and runTests().
        Parameters:
        pathToSrc - The dot separated or slash separated path starting after the base directory of your project and leading to the content root.
        localTestRoot - The dot separated path to the root package of your tests. This defaults to TARGET_DOT_NAME_DEFAULT

            boolean fullTrace,

      • runTests

        public void runTests(java.lang.String targetDotName,
            boolean recurse,
            boolean fullTrace,
            boolean scanNonTestClasses)
        Executes the following functions serially:
        • queueTests(String, boolean, boolean)
        • executeQueuedTests()
        • prettyPrint(boolean)
        The default parameters for the class are used unless overridden by a parameter of this or any other overload of runTests().
        Parameters:
        targetDotName - The dot-separated name of the package or class to be scanned. If the TestDriver was constructed with a localTestRoot parameter, that localTestRoot path will automatically be prefixed by targetDotName.
        queueTests() will attempt to fix format errors in the targetDotName.
        recurse - Set to true if you would like to queue tests in sub packages of targetDotName.
        fullTrace - Set to true in order to see the full stack trace for each error.
        scanNonTestClasses - Set to true if you would like to queue tests discovered in any class even if it does not have the @LiteClass annotation. This is useful if want to add tests to a class without making a new class to house the tests.

      • queueTests

        See queueTests(String, boolean, boolean)

      • queueTests

        public void queueTests(boolean recurse,
              boolean scanNonTestClasses)
        See queueTests(String, boolean, boolean)

      • queueTests

        public void queueTests(java.lang.String targetDotName,
              boolean recurse,
              boolean scanNonTestClasses)
        Scans classes in specified package or the specific class specified for methods that have the following conditions:
        • are marked with @LiteTest
        • are public
        • return void
        • have no parameters
        Classes with 'Lite' anywhere in their name are ignored.
        NOTE: Default parameters for the class will be used if this function is invoked using an overload that does not supply all of the parameters.
        Parameters:
        targetDotName - The dot-separated name of the package or class to be scanned. If the TestDriver was constructed with a localTestRoot parameter, that localTestRoot path will automatically be prefixed by targetDotName.
        The method will attempt to fix format errors in the targetDotName.
        recurse - Set to true if you would like to queue tests in sub packages of targetDotName.
        scanNonTestClasses - Set to true if you would like to queue tests discovered in any class even if it does not have the @LiteClass annotation. This is useful if want to add tests to a class without making a new class to house the tests.

      • executeQueuedTests

        public void executeQueuedTests()
        Execute the tests that have been queued using the queueTests() method or one of its overloads. Nothing will be printed when this method is invoked. It runs the tests, then organizes the results behind the scenes for analysis and printing later on. If you want to see the results of the tests, use a print function such as prettyPrint() or one of its overloads.

      • prettyPrint

        public void prettyPrint()
        Nicely prints out the results of executeQueuedTests(). Currently this method displays a shortened version of the errors. Use prettyPrint(true) to see more of the stack trace.

      • prettyPrint

        public void prettyPrint(boolean fullTrace)
        Same as prettyPrint() but with the option to see the stack trace.
        Parameters:
        fullTrace - Set to true in order to see the full stack trace for each error.

      • reset

        public void reset()
        Reset in preparation for new tests.
